channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Deaths From Swine Flu Rise
item.description: Deaths from a swine flu outbreak in Iran have more than tripled in the past three weeks to at least 112.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Man Is Suspected of Killing Relative at Essex Nursing Home
item.description: A man in his 80s was arrested Monday, suspected of fatally shooting an 81-year-old woman who was a fellow nursing home resident.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Poland: Law Altering Top Court Goes Into Effect Despite Criticism
item.description: The new law which affects how Poland’s highest court makes rulings, is a move that critics say will paralyze the court and erode checks and balances on government powers.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Iran Hands Over Stockpile of Enriched Uranium to Russia
item.description: The move fulfills an important step in the nuclear deal struck with world powers, and American officials say that it may now be only weeks before the accord will go into effect.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Suspected Boko Haram Attacks Kill Scores in Nigeria
item.description: At least 52 people were killed and 124 injured in bombings and shootings in the city of Maiduguri.
item.dc:creator: IBRAHIM SAWAB

item.title: Khartoum Journal: Sudan Is a Waypoint on East Africans’ Trek to Europe
item.description: Thousands of migrants, especially from Eritrea and Ethiopia, reach Sudan every year hoping to earn money to pay a smuggler for passage to Libya and, ultimately, Europe.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:description: Eritrean asylum seekers meet at the Wad Sharifey refugee camp in eastern Sudan, near the border with Eritrea.

item.title: A Lion Expert Who Isn’t Inclined to Turn Tail
item.description: Determined to preserve African lions, biologist Craig Packer has antagonized hunters, government officials and even other conservationists.
item.category: Lions in the Balance: Man-Eaters, Manes, and Men with Guns (Book)
item.dc:creator: ERICA GOODE
item.media:description: A lioness descends from a tree in the Serengeti.

item.title: Israel and Brazil at Impasse Over Ambassador Appointment
item.description: Signaling its displeasure, the Brazilian government has yet to approve Israel’s nomination of a former settler leader as its next ambassador to Brasília.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and VINOD SREEHARSHA
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dani Dayan, Israel's choice for ambassador to Brazil, in the West Bank in 2012. The Brazilian government has yet to approve his nomination.

item.title: Iraqi Forces Retake Center of Ramadi From ISIS
item.description: The militants fled the western city’s government headquarters, although pockets of resistance remained in the north and east.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: FALIH HASSAN and SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: A soldier in a heavily damaged building in the Huz neighborhood of Ramadi, Iraq, on Sunday.

item.title: Global Health: Zika Virus, a Mosquito-Borne Infection, May Threaten Brazil’s Newborns
item.description: An increase in the number of infants born in Brazil with a form of brain damage has been blamed on the Zika virus.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: A woman in Brazil holds her daughter, who was born with microcephaly. An increase in the disease — a form of brain damage — has been blamed on the Zika virus.

item.title: Global Health: Mosquito-Borne Infection May Threaten Newborns in Brazil
item.description: An increase in the number of infants born in Brazil with a form of brain damage has been blamed on the Zika virus.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: A woman in Brazil holds her daughter, who was born with microcephaly. An increase in the disease — a form of brain damage — has been blamed on the Zika virus.

item.title: Squeezed by Low Oil Prices, Saudi Arabia Cuts Spending to Shrink Deficit
item.description: The official Saudi news media reported that the Finance Ministry would cut spending, adopt new taxes and reduce price subsidies for fuel, water and power.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: India Offers Atypical Video Challenges
item.description: Both local entertainment companies, as well as Netflix, Amazon and 21st Century Fox, hope to persuade Indians to pay for online streaming, but changing current habits will be difficult.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL
item.media:credit: Asmita Parelkar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aparajita Jamwal, a yoga instructor, filming an instructional video.

item.title: David Cameron Defends Flood Record as Northern England Is Drenched
item.description: Britain’s Environmental Agency warned that the country needed “a complete rethink” of its flood defenses as roads in the north remained under water.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and STANLEY REED
item.media:credit: Anna Gowthorpe/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Emergency workers waded through a flooded street in York, England, on Monday. Prime Minister David Cameron defended the government’s record on flood defenses during a visit there, saying that it had committed to spend 2.3 billion pounds.

item.title: Syrian Journalist Who Documented ISIS Atrocities Is Killed in Turkey
item.description: The death of the journalist, Naji Jerf, on Sunday, came a day before he and his family were to fly to France, where they were seeking asylum.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: KARAM SHOUMALI
item.media:description: Mourners gathered around the body of Naji Jerf, a journalist and filmmaker, in Gaziantep, Turkey, on Monday. Mr. Jerf and his family were scheduled to fly on Monday to France, where they were seeking asylum.

item.title: Burundi Crackdown Puts Hutus and Tutsis, and the West, on Edge
item.description: With rebel attacks and government raids raising tensions between ethnic groups that have a deadly history, the hope is that negotiations set to begin this week will defuse this crisis.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: A portrait of Egide Niyongere in front of his coffin at his funeral in Bujumbura, Burundi. Witnesses said Mr. Niyongere had been killed during counterinsurgency attacks by government forces in mid-December.

item.title: Letter From Europe: The E.U. Migrant Crisis, Told in 2 Startling Numbers
item.description: More than one million migrants have made their way to Europe this year, but only 190 of them have been formally relocated.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN
item.media:description: Migrants at a camp in Calais, France. For migrants who came to the city in the hopes of moving on to England, relocation to provincial towns in France is probably not a long-term solution.

item.title: Japan and South Korea Settle Dispute Over Wartime ‘Comfort Women’
item.description: The deal, in which Japan made an apology and promised an $8.3 million payment, may help mend ties between the countries.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: The foreign minister of Japan, Fumio Kishida, left, and his counterpart from South Korea, Yun Byung-se, at a news conference on Monday.

item.title: China Detains 12 People Over Shenzhen Landslide, Police Say
item.description: A former district official whose office oversaw the dumpsite died after jumping from a building, the state media also quoted the police as saying.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Excavators during a rescue operation after a landslide buried buildings at an industrial park in Shenzhen, China.

item.title: Sinosphere: As China Hungers for Coal, ‘Behemoth’ Studies the Ravages at the Source
item.description: Zhao Liang’s film “Behemoth” depicts the harmful effects of mining on Inner Mongolia’s grasslands, and its people.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:description: In Zhao Liang’s film “Behemoth,” which uses on-screen text adapted from Dante’s “Divine Comedy,” a coal miner plays a role akin to that of Virgil, the guide, holding a mirror on his back as he leads viewers.
